block.p: Shaky Footing

If Alabama cannot straighten out its kicking game, the Crimson Tide may have a long afternoon in Gainesville today against No. 5 Florida (4-0). Alabama lost in double overtime to Arkansas last week, 24-23, when the freshman Leigh Tiffin missed three field-goal attempts and an extra point.
Alabama (3-1) will also be challenged by the Gators' offense, which is averaging 289.8 yards passing and 175.8 rushing.
Shaky Footing

If Alabama cannot straighten out its kicking game, the Crimson Tide may have a long afternoon in Gainesville today against No. 5 Florida (4-0). Alabama lost in double overtime to Arkansas last week, 24-23, when the freshman Leigh Tiffin missed three field-goal attempts and an extra point.
Alabama (3-1) will also be challenged by the Gators' offense, which is averaging 289.8 yards passing and 175.8 rushing.
Joe Kines, Alabama's defensive coordinator, was quoted on the team's Web site talking about Florida's offense:

''I have never seen a system that has all the parts of football: the power, the zone, the option, play action, the empty, five wideouts, short yardage, two tight ends. I don't think there is a part of football they don't cover.''
Other major games today:
No. 1 Ohio State at No. 13 Iowa
No. 3 U.S.C. at Washington State
No. 24 Georgia Tech at No. 11 Virginia Tech
Purdue at No. 12 Notre Dame
In Division III, Trinity's 31-game winning streak will be on the line against its New England Small College Athletic Conference rival Williams at Weston Field in Williamstown, Mass.
Rolling Right Along
Texas Christian lost to Brigham Young on Thursday night, ending what was the longest active winning streak in N.C.A.A. Division I (13 games). The nation's longest active winning streaks.
A Modest TV Premiere
On Sept. 30, 1939 -- 67 years ago today -- a college football game was televised for the first time.
Fordham, then a national power, played Waynesburg (Pa.) at Randalls Island Stadium. Fordham won, 34-7. The game was shown on W2XBS, an experimental station that became WNBC-TV.
According to estimates at the time, there were perhaps 200 sets in the metropolitan New York area, and the game attracted 500 viewers.
The play-by-play announcer was Bill Stern, a leading sportscaster of that era, and the pregame interviews were handled by a 26-year-old Mel Allen.
Fifty years after the game, Dom Principe, a star fullback for Fordham, told the sports historian Stanley Grosshandler, ''The fact that the game was televised was of no significance to us.''

Jack McPhee, the referee in the game, said: ''When I returned to my home in Youngstown, Ohio, I told my wife about it. She was all excited, asking me what television was and how did it work. Of course, I did not know.''
FRANK LITSKY (NYT)
COLLEGE FOOTBALL
